Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Phylogenomics - New Computational Methods through Stochastic Modeling and Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, modeling and analysis techniques from probability theory will be used to study several important computational problems in the area of phylogenomics, i.e., the integration of genome analysis and systematic studies. Various mechanisms such as hybridization events, lateral gene transfers, gene duplications and losses, and incomplete lineage sorting commonly lead to incongruences between inferred gene genealogies. As a result, one is led to consider forests of gene histories as well as more complex network representations of the evolutionary history of life. The main goals of the research are to improve large-scale likelihood-based gene tree estimation, develop computational methods to assemble species phylogenies from gene histories, and detect network-like signal in molecular data. Drawing on a combination of ideas from discrete probability, algorithms, and mathematical statistics, novel methodologies will be developed that are both statistically accurate and computationally efficient for these challenging inference problems.

Biologists face major statistical and computational challenges in modeling, analyzing, and interpreting the massive genetic datasets produced by next-generation technologies, including genomic variation within populations, whole genomes from multiple species, and environmental samples. In particular, high-throughput sequencing is transforming the reconstruction of the Tree of Life, a fundamental problem in biology which provides insights into the study of evolution, adaptation, and speciation. Through the development, implementation, and broad dissemination of new practical algorithms for phylogenomic studies based on mathematical analysis, this project will help advance the state of knowledge in evolutionary biology and contribute to the numerous benefits to society of phylogenetic research. Integration of research and education is a major component of this proposal. In addition to providing training for graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, new undergraduate and graduate courses will be developed and research experiences for undergraduates will be an important part of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Tree of Life is a common visualization of the evolutionary relationships between species, which has found numerous important applications in evolutionary biology, viral epidemiology, and cancer studies, to name a few. Reconstructing the Tree of Life, as well as more complex network representations of evolution (see the supporting image), starting from massive amounts of genetic data is a challenging data science problem. This project made significant advances on the mathematical foundations of this problem by developing the theoretical underpinnings for standard as well as novel reconstruction approaches. Some key outcomes include:

1 - New reconstruction algorithms for a class of phylogenetic networks, widely used in the study of viral and bacterial evolution in particular, were designed together with accuracy guarantees improving significantly over past methods. Novel reconstruction methodologies were also developed to deal with complex genome-wide evolutionary histories, such as due to horizontal gene transfer or incomplete lineage sorting. Impossibility results establishing the optimality of these methods in some regimes were also derived. 

2 - Unexpected connections with an important public health problem were discovered. Respondent-driven sampling is a standard statistical methodology to study hard-to-reach or stigmatized populations. Using the mathematical techniques developed in this project, significantly more accurate estimation strategies were obtained in this context.

3 - Several undergraduate and graduate students as well as a postdoctoral researcher were trained at the inter-disciplinary interface of mathematics, computer science and biology. In particular, the project included a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) component.

4 - A new course entitled Modern Discrete Probability covering the mathematical techniques used in this project, with wide applicability in other data science applications for example, was developed at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. Extensive educational materials, freely available on the course website, were created.
